intro: Acer campestre f. variegatum, commonly known as the variegated field maple, is a cultivar of the field maple tree. It is characterized by its distinctive variegated leaves, which display a mix of green, white, and yellow hues. This plant is native to Europe and thrives in temperate climates. It typically grows as a small to medium-sized tree or shrub, reaching heights of up to 10 meters. The leaves are palmately lobed and turn vibrant shades of red and orange in the autumn, adding ornamental value to gardens and landscapes.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acer campestre f. variegatum is primarily native to parts of Europe, including the British Isles, Scandinavia, and Central Europe. It is commonly found in woodlands, hedgerows, and along roadsides in these regions. This variety of the common horse chestnut is adapted to temperate climates and thrives in well-drained soils. It is often seen as a shrub or small tree, reaching heights of up to 8 meters. Its variegated leaves make it a popular ornamental plant in gardens and parks.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acer campestre f. variegatum was mainly introduced to ornamental horticulture due to its attractive variegated foliage. It is commonly found in gardens and landscaped areas where its unique leaf patterns add visual interest. The plant is well-suited for temperate climates and can thrive in a variety of soil types. Its introduction has led to its cultivation in many regions beyond its native range. However, it is important to monitor its spread to prevent potential ecological impacts.
